newsitem.title: USA: Harley-Davidson bikes hog roads in Maine city.
newsitem.headline: Harley-Davidson bikes hog roads in Maine city.

text.p: It was "Hog Heaven" in Maine's largest city Friday and even the governor hopes to have his Harley-Davidson motorcycle on the road before the weekend is over.
A motorcycle parade kicked off the gathering of "HOG" -- Harley Owners Group -- which draws people from around the United States and Canada to show off their bikes and accompanying regalia.
"All these people are having fun with their motorcycles. That's what it's all about," William Davidson, grandson of one of the company's founders, said.
The throaty roar of motorcycles echoed across downtown Portland, where some streets were closed except for bikes and a lighted message board atop a building flashed "Hog Heaven."
Some 5,000 people are attending the two-day rally. The owners group, affiliated with Milwaukee-based Harley-Davidson Inc, claims to be the largest motorcycle group in the world with 320,000 members.
Events range from riding competitions to a "Stud Your Duds" demonstration of adding metal studs to leather clothes.
Gov. Angus King, who owns a Harley Dynaglide, had planned to participate in the parade but was kept at the statehouse in Augusta by legislative business. He still hoped to attend the rally Saturday.
"Why do I like to ride? It takes my mind off my work," said King, who sometimes goes riding with another Maine Harley-Davidson owner, the state supreme court chief justice.
Owners of other brands of motorcycles were noticeably absent from Portland streets in recent days, although a Honda motorcycle was spotted in HOG's impromptu street parking lot.
"My dad's got the Harley. I'm going to get a real bike when I get the money," explained the owner, who then asked the reporter not to print his name.
